 Here we go:
 First of all, I don't want to ban guns in the USA; I'd favor restrictions there.
 
 But in Europe we do very well with our gun laws. After WW2 the people in Europe were tired of fighting and as a result of this the Western European countries stated strict gun laws; in effect, nearly nobody owns a gun legally.
 In addition, penalties for crimes are much higher when committed with guns. Imo this lead to a different kind of mentality among criminals (I know this sounds weird) because it was harder to obtain a gun and even if you had one it would bring you into very big trouble as soon as police suspected you (as the criminal is rated as more dangerous and therefore gets more attention). The common criminals who commit crimes (and now I am talking for Germany only, I don't got stats from other countries) don't use guns. The risk is too high and the effect is not worth it. Real criminals try to get a gun and they always find a way to acquire one but these guys aren't scared of armed resistance too much either.
 That's why I (and most Europeans) don't see any need for more guns in our society. The first ones that would make use of a new law would be the criminals. Gun accidents would also inevitably rise and these numbers alone would maybe exceed the numbers of gun crime victims we have nowadays.
 
 But as I said at the beginning, this is only about Europe; the US already have too many guns around to get rid of them all.

A few words on the points being made about the buying, selling, and giving of firearms. I bought my first .22 at about 15 years of age. Walked into the best sporting goods store in my town, and walked out with the weapon. I wasn't asked if I had been trained properly, ( I had ) nor was I asked any questions. Unfortunately, I traded it years later. I wish I hadn't. I bought another .22 at age 17, which I still have, and which I will pass on to one of my grandchildren. 
 
 Personally, I find the age restriction, to be stupid and basically uncalled for. See above. Are kids really any different now than then. Some are, but most aren't. 
 
 GGs are caught up, and gun owners have gone along with, in this silly argument about background checks, to the point of being rediculous. Some people are criminals, but most aren't. Some people do stupid things, and though all do at certain times, most are not perennially eaten up with a case pf the 'stupids'. Laws against being stupid or doing stupid things would have all of us in jail.
 
 A law can not look into the future and see who will commit a crime, nor can it predetermine who may go nuts. God help this country if technology ever gets to the level where such things can occur.
 
 Life is a crapshoot, at best. The only guarantee is we must die. What may happen after that is where one's faith plays a part of their lives. 
 
 Firearms are still a legal commodity in our country. What's changed? 
 
 Just a few thoughts from an firm believer in the right of individuals to control their own personal destiny, free from the encumberances imposed by the fearful, who believing government should protect us from cradle to grave, would try to determine what is best for all of us.
